turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Hello?

turns.text: Hello. Can you hear me well?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Uh uh yes. I think. It's a bit better. It's a bit, it's a bit, it's not very clear. But <UNIN/> let's continue anyway.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Uh, OK. Let's start again. So how can I help you sir?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yes. So, it's been a few days now. I have like a sore, and a red skin. It's kind of, it's really itchy, and it's like super annoying. So I'd like to find something quick to solve it.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, mostly like my chest, my, my hands, my arms. Like, like really, it's it's super annoying. Like it's itching a lot, like all the time. And

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I can't even sleep at night. <UNIN/> I really need something quickly to, to solve it. Because even at work I, I can, when I'm in a meeting and I have to, like uh think about my work, I can't focus, I can't actually focus on my work. It's really annoying because I can't actually think about, uh, what I have to say. I'm always like, uh, disturbed by this disease.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No no, OK. <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> I'm <UNSURE>certain </UNSURE> this is obviously affecting you. And uh we'll try our very best to get get this sorted out for you. Um, have you had anything like this before in the past?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Um so yes. Uh earlier I was like prescribed for my eczema.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: And <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> they gave me like some cream, and something to, uh when I like <UNIN/> shower, when I was in the shower, had to put something. But um

turns.text: OK.

turns.text: Did it help?

turns.text: Um I mean, at that time yes. That's, those symptoms, like these symptoms appear like, when the symptoms appeared again, I tried those and it didn't work.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I've tried a few things. Like I bought a, a steroid cream at the pharmacy last night. But it apparently didn't help, because it's still itching a lot today. Uh, yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNSURE>OK</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.text: OK, steroid, OK. <UNIN/> um <UNIN/> would you say these symptoms are very similar to your eczema symptoms, or different?

turns.speaker: PATIENT

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Like <UNSURE>pretty</UNSURE>, yeah when, like I like, for instance hiking, during the weekend. And

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I am, I can't really do it anymore, because it's like very <UNIN/> like I wanted to do that last weekend. And because super painful, and I I have to take like showers every day to be able to, cannot uh ease this itching part, which is very very annoying.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No. <UNIN/> Well OK. That's <UNIN/> so you mentioned the itchiness. Um you also mentioned it's been quite sore.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um have you, have you noticed any uh bleeding or discharge from your skins?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNIN/>. OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No. Um so my skin is a bit cracked in some parts, like kind of cracked, if you see what I mean. But uh, yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.text: You've not, haven't uh seen any other uh pus or blood, coming out of your skin.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No. And you mentioned it all started three days ago.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Are you, four days ago. Are you aware of any triggers, or anything that you may have done, that may have caused your symptoms to start?

turns.text: Four days ago.

turns.text: So for example, have you changed your uh shower gel, any clothing?

Because I I haven't, and I don't understand <UNIN/> I cannot, um afraid of asking people around me because it's cannot you know um, I don't feel really comfortable asking about these questions. It's kind of intimate that. So I <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/> your help now.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Mm.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Mm. No no, OK. That's OK. Um

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Fine, so just to resummarize. For the last four days, you've had very itchy skin, very sore skin all over your body, mainly your chest. And did you also mention your arms and legs as well?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <UNSURE>Yeah</UNSURE>.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, no. Just the chest, hands and like, like inside the elbows. Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. <UNIN/> anything on your face at all?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Am I what?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: On your face?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: On my face? No.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No, OK. And apart from this, any other symptoms have you noticed? For example, have you noticed any temperature or fevers?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No. <UNIN/> just very itchy. Nothing else.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Itchy. OK. So your, your bowels are working OK?

turns.text: No.

turns.text: Um <UNIN/> so I had eczema before. So maybe it's <UNSURE>disease</UNSURE>, but it seems like more uh, like uh my eczema was only on the arms. So, I'm I'm not sure. I I really have no idea.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. That's OK. So um, normally at this stage I like to examine you. Um

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: To see the rash itself, to see exactly what type of rash it is. But from what you've told me, you mentioned it's, you've got some dry skin and some, uh cracked skin as well.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Uh and has been very itchy. And so would your um

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Uh your your background of eczema. Um

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNSURE>So</UNSURE>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Sorry to say, there's a couple of questions I wanted to ask you, which I completely forgot, my apologies. Um, apart from the eczema, do you have any other medical problems I should be aware of?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh, no. I just had asthma in the past. But not anymore.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Not anymore, OK. And do you take any regular medications at the moment?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh no.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No, OK. Do you have any allergies to anything?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: I <UNIN/> like some <UNIN/>, sorry? Yeah?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/> sorry I said do you have any allergies to anything?

turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Hello? Yes.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/> can you hear me? That's alright I think it <UNIN/>. Uh do you have any allergies at all?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Ohh, allergies. Uh, no.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No, OK. Um and tell me about your um uh your situation at home. Who do you live with?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh so, I live with a few flatmates. I'm a, so you know I'm thirty one. Uh I, yeah I'm I have a full time job. And so I'm living with a few people to save money.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. And what do you do for work?

turns.text: Uh I work uh at a pharmaceutical company.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: So it's been a, it's been a few years now. Uh it's uh, it's kind of interesting. We're working I'm a, like a kind of project manager. Uh I mean, do you want to, to know more about it?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Uh no no no that's <UNIN/>, that's absolutely fine. Um just a couple of questions I want to ask you, which can sometimes affect your symptoms, is, do you smoke at all?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: No. And do you drink much in the way of alcohol?

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: Uh you know, <UNIN/> once in a while I can, I like hanging out with people once in a while. So yeah I'd say a few, a few beers per week. Something like this. Nothing, nothing crazy. I used to drink a lot more when I was younger. But it's been, it's been a while. <UNIN/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. OK. OK I've got to say, at this stage I've got to say <UNIN/> this sound quality is not uh great. But I will continue because we've come this far. Um

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: So um, based on everything you mentioned <UNSURE>Sarah </UNSURE>, <UNIN/> I do wonder whether this is a flare-up of your eczema. Um

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: The reason being that you said it was quite itchy. Um it's mainly affecting your chest and your back.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um and uh, having looked at your skin, uh the the the rash does appear quite familiar. Um you mentioned <UNIN/> using steroid creams, yesterday.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: <INAUDIBLE_SPEECH/>

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um from the pharmacy. I wonder whether giving you a stronger prescription of a <UNIN/> of a steroid may be beneficial.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Uh, which I'm happy to prescribe to you today. As well as, I'm going to give you something, some emollients, which helps to moisturize the skin.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um which <UNIN/> use in the bath and shower. And it's definitely worth um using that for the first seven to ten days.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Uh before we make the decision on whether it's working or not.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um it's also worth um using antihistamines, which you can sometimes buy over counter.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: And uh, um it's also worth keeping a diary of any triggers which are affecting your symptoms, anything you wear or anything you use, in terms of shower gels or soap.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Because if that's causing your symptoms, then we need to have a discussion about an eczema CU.

turns.text: OK. Yes, I have tried antihistamines, uh lately, but it didn't really help.

turns.text: I have tried uh antihistamines, but uh but it didn't really help.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: <UNIN/> OK. So it's something for you to think about. <UNIN/> you can get different types of antihistamines. I can give you something a little bit stronger today as well.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um, something like Fexofenadine, which I can give to you today. It's definitely worth trying, and it's not going to do you any harm.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: OK.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Um but I <UNIN/> think using the steroids and the emollients, um on a regular basis

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: Uh over the next week to ten days, should hopefully <UNIN/> control your symptoms. But do come back and see me next week, if things don't get better.

turns.speaker: PATIENT
turns.text: That sounds good.

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK? Um do you have any questions for me?

turns.speaker: DOCTOR
turns.text: OK. Well I wish you all the best.
